modifierText: Use only simple examples with basic intervals like (1, 5) or [2, 6).
Include finite sets like {1, 2, 3} in addition to intervals.
Use intervals, finite sets, and also include fundamental sets like ℝ and ∅.
Include intervals, finite sets, ℝ, ∅ and introduce elements like fractions (e.g. 1/2) or radicals (e.g. √2).
Include more advanced expressions with set operations like ∪ (union), ∩ (intersection), and \ (difference).
Combine all previous elements and add complex nested structures using different brackets like (), [], {} with operations and symbolic elements.
Use only interval notation like [a, b] or (a, b).
Use only finite sets. Do not use infinite sets or intervals.
Include only positive numbers in the sets. Exclude zero and negative numbers.
Ensure that all sets are disjoint. No element should appear in more than one set.

Your generated set must be disjoint from the set ${s:}.
- Do NOT include any number inside ${s:}.
- Avoid any overlap, including endpoints unless intervals are open.
- The output must NOT intersect with ${s:}.
